hints_html:
Simplify the function first as was done in part (a) and then use the chain rule.

You can also differentiate this using logarithmic differentiation.
hints_latex:
Simplify the function first as was done in
{part
(a)} and then use the chain rule.
You can also differentiate this using logarithmic differentiation.
hints_raw:
Simplify the function first as was done in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH110/December_2013/Question_06_(a)|part (a)]] and then use the chain rule.
You can also differentiate this using logarithmic differentiation.
question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
Since we have simplified, we can simply apply the chain rule to it using \(u = x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3\).

\[\begin{aligned} f(u) &= e^u & f'(u) &= e^u\\ u(x) & x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 & u'(x) &= 3x^2 + 4x + 1.\end{aligned}\]

Combining, we get:

\(f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}\)

Alternatively, we can start with the initial function and use log-diff:

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) &= \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\\ \ln(f(x)) &= \ln\left(\frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\right)\\ &= \ln\left(e^{\left(x^3\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{\left(2x^2\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{x}\right) - \ln\left({e^3}\right)\\ &= x^3 \ln\left(e\right) + 2x^2 \ln\left(e\right) +x \ln\left(e\right) - 3\ln\left(e\right)\\ \ln(f(x))&= x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\\ {\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \ln(f(x)) &= {\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \left(x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\right)\\ \frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 3x^2 + 4x +1\\ f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right) f(x)\\ f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right)\cdot \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Since we have simplified, we can simply apply the chain rule to it using
$u = x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3$.

\begin{align*}
f(u) &= e^u & f'(u) &= e^u\\
u(x) &  x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 & u'(x) &=  3x^2 + 4x + 1.
\end{align*}

Combining, we get:

$f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}$

Alternatively, we can start with the initial function and use log-diff:

\begin{align*}
f(x) &= \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\\
\ln(f(x)) &= \ln\left(\frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\right)\\
&= \ln\left(e^{\left(x^3\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{\left(2x^2\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{x}\right) - \ln\left({e^3}\right)\\
&= x^3 \ln\left(e\right) + 2x^2 \ln\left(e\right) +x \ln\left(e\right) - 3\ln\left(e\right)\\
\ln(f(x))&= x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\\
{\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \ln(f(x)) &= {\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \left(x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\right)\\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 3x^2 + 4x +1\\
f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right) f(x)\\
f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right)\cdot \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
Since we have simplified, we can simply apply the chain rule to it using <math>u = x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3</math>.

<math>\begin{align}
f(u) &= e^u & f'(u) &= e^u\\
u(x) &  x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3 & u'(x) &=  3x^2 + 4x + 1.\end{align}</math>

Combining, we get:

<math>f'(x) = \left(3x^2 + 4x + 1\right)\cdot e^{x^3 + 2x^2 + x - 3}</math>
Alternatively, we can start with the initial function and use log-diff:

<math>\begin{align}
f(x) &= \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\\
\ln(f(x)) &= \ln\left(\frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\right)\\
&= \ln\left(e^{\left(x^3\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{\left(2x^2\right)}\right) + \ln\left(e^{x}\right) - \ln\left({e^3}\right)\\
&= x^3 \ln\left(e\right) + 2x^2 \ln\left(e\right) +x \ln\left(e\right) - 3\ln\left(e\right)\\
\ln(f(x))&= x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\\
{\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \ln(f(x)) &= {\frac{{\rm d}}{{\rm d}x}} \left(x^3 + 2x^2 +x - 3\right)\\
\frac{f'(x)}{f(x)} &= 3x^2 + 4x +1\\
f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right) f(x)\\
f'(x) &= \left(3x^2 + 4x +1\right)\cdot \frac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}\\\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.\end{aligned}\]

(b) Find the derivative of \(f(x)\).
statement_raw:
Consider the function: <math>f(x) = \dfrac{e^{\left(x^3\right)}e^{\left(2x^2\right)}e^{x}}{e^3}.</math>

'''(b)''' Find the derivative of <math>f(x)</math>.
